entries.name: Thunderous Fortitude
entries: You have resistance to thunder and lightning damage.

entries.name: Embrace the Tempest
entries: You know the {@spell Thunderclap} cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell Witch Bolt} spell once with this trait as a 1st-level spell, and you regain the ability to cast it this way when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for these spells.
In the highest reaches of the Plane of Air an endless storm rages, giving birth to energetic and impulsive elementals.

As a Storm Genasi, you have inherited the raw and unpredictable nature of thunder and lightning. Storm Genasi are often quick to action and volatile in their choices, and are rarely content to sit quietly or contained.

Some Storm Genasi can be mistaken for ordinary humanoids, however the electricity dancing in their eyes and jumping between strands of their hair may betray their true ancestry. Most Storm Genasi have blue eyes, though yellow and other colors have been documented as well. Their hair can range from platinum to blonde, to orange, with some even having bright blue or green. Their skin, like most Genasi, can range from humanoid flesh tones to more dramatic blues, greens, and yellows. Some Storm Genasi can be seen with electricity arcing just beneath the skin, or walk with noticeably thunderous steps.
Storm Genasi are often quick speakers or exceptionally loud ones.

Those who think of other planes at all consider them remote, distant realms, but planar influence can be felt throughout the world. It sometimes manifests in beings who, through an accident of birth, carry the power of the planes in their blood. The genasi are one such people, the offspring of genies and mortals.

The Elemental Planes are often inhospitable to natives of the Material Plane: crushing earth, searing flames, boundless skies, and endless seas make visiting these places dangerous for even a short time. The powerful genies, however, do not face such troubles when venturing into the mortal world. They adapt well to the mingled elements of the Material Plane, and they sometimes visit whether of their own volition or compelled by magic. Some genies can adopt mortal guise and travel incognito.

During these visits, a mortal might catch a genies eye. Friendship forms, romance blooms, and sometimes children result. These children are genasi: individuals with ties to two worlds, yet belonging to neither. Some genasi are born of mortal-genie unions, others have two genasi as parents, and a rare few have a genie further up their family tree, manifesting an elemental heritage that's lain dormant for generations.

Occasionally, genasi result from exposure to a surge of elemental power, through phenomena such as an eruption from the Inner Planes or a planar convergence. Elemental energy saturates any creatures in the area and might alter their nature enough that their offspring with other mortals are born as genasi.

entries.name: Heirs to Elemental Power
entries: Genasi inherit something from both sides of their dual nature. They resemble humans but have unusual skin color (red, green, blue, or gray), and there is something odd about them. The elemental blood flowing through their veins manifests differently in each genasi, often as magical power.

Seen in silhouette, a genasi can usually pass for human. Those of earth or water descent tend to be heavier, while those of air or fire tend to be lighter. A given genasi might have some features reminiscent of the mortal parent (pointed ears from an elf, a stockier frame and thick hair from a dwarf, small hands and feet from a halfling, exceedingly large eyes from a gnome, and so on).
Genasi almost never have contact with their elemental parents. Genies seldom have interest in their mortal offspring, seeing them as accidents. Many feel nothing for their genasi children at all.

Some genasi live as outcasts, driven into exile for their unsettling appearance and strange magic, or assuming leadership of savage humanoids and weird cults in untamed lands. Others gain positions of great influence, especially where elemental beings are revered. A few genasi leave the Material Plane to find refuge in the households of their genie parents.

entries.name: Wild and Confident
entries: Genasi rarely lack confidence, seeing themselves as equal to almost any challenge in their path. This certainty might manifest as graceful self-assurance in one genasi and as arrogance in another. Such self-confidence can sometimes blind genasi to risk, and their great plans often get them and others into trouble.
Too much failure can chip away at even a genasis sense of self, so they constantly push themselves to improve, honing their talents and perfecting their craft.

entries.name: Genasi Lands
entries: As rare beings, genasi might go their entire lives without encountering another one of their kind. There are no great genasi cities or empires. Genasi seldom have communities of their own and typically adopt the cultures and societies into which they are born. The more strange their appearance, the harder time they have. Many genasi lose themselves in teeming cities, where their distinctiveness hardly raises an eyebrow in places accustomed to a variety of different people.

Those living on the frontier, though, have a much harder time. People there tend to be less accepting of differences. Sometimes a cold shoulder and a suspicious glare are the best genasi can hope for; in more backward places, they face ostracism and even violence from people who mistake them for fiends. Facing a hard life, these genasi seek isolation in the wilds, making their homes in mountains or forests, near lakes, or underground.

Most air and fire genasi in the Realms are descendants of the djinn and efreet who once ruled Calimshan. When those rulers were overthrown, their planetouched children were scattered. Over thousands of years, the bloodlines of those genasi have spread into other lands. Though far from common, air and fire genasi are more likely to be found in the western regions of Faerun, along the coast from Calimshan north up to the Sword Coast, and into the Western Heartlands to the east. Some remain in their ancient homeland.

In contrast, water and earth genasi have no common history. Individuals have difficulty tracing their own lineage, and bloodlines occasionally skip a generation or two. Many earth genasi originated in the North and spread out from there. Water genasi come from coastal areas, the largest concentration of them hailing from the regions surrounding the Sea of Fallen Stars.

The distant land of Zakhara is known only in legends to most inhabitants of Faerun. There, genies and spellcasters enter into bargains, and genasi can result from such pacts. Those genasi have been sources of great weal and woe in the history of that land.

entries.name: Genasi Names
entries: Genasi use the naming conventions of the people among whom they were raised. They might later assume distinctive names to capture their heritage, such as Flame, Ember, Wave, or Onyx.

entries.name: Magmatic Glow
entries: Your body is capable of emitting light which glows like that of the magma which courses through the earth deep beneath your feet. You can create bright light for 30 feet, and dim light for another 30 feet.

entries.name: Molten Body
entries: You have resistance to fire damage, however cold damage reduces your speed by 5 feet until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Release the Core
entries: Your ties with the most primal component of the world are not easily contained, but you have mastered your control of it. When you damage a creature with an attack or a touch range spell, you can coat your hand or weapon in magma, causing the attack or spell to deal fire damage to the creature. This extra damage equals your level. You may also use this feature to ignite a flammable item that is not being worn or held or, if the item is made of stone or metal, you may attempt to melt it. You can use this feature twice per long or short rest.
Between the Planes of Earth and Fire lies the Plane of Magma, a land of primal creation.
As a Magma Genasi, you have inherited both the timeless endurance and the explosive fury of the volcanoes which shape the world. You are unshakable in both your decisions and your resolve.

Magma Genasi can often be confused for their Earth cousins, however the lava which flows through the pores and cracks in their flesh quickly breaks that illusion. Their skin can range from a glassy obsidian black, to a coarse and pitted grey or tan pumice, or even the colors of some more brilliant minerals. Magma Genasi are cool to the touch, but a heat dwells underneath, ready to spring forth. Some magma genasi have normal hair, with as much variety of color as their skin, while others have locks that seem to be carved of stone, and can melt to lava under extreme emotion.
Magma genasi voices may sound coarse for the first few syllables after not speaking for a while, but quickly smooth out to deep but even flow.

Those who think of other planes at all consider them remote, distant realms, but planar influence can be felt throughout the world. It sometimes manifests in beings who, through an accident of birth, carry the power of the planes in their blood. The genasi are one such people, the offspring of genies and mortals.

The powerful genies, however, do not face such troubles when venturing into the mortal world. They adapt well to the mingled elements of the Material Plane, and they sometimes visit whether of their own volition or compelled by magic. Some genies can adopt mortal guise and travel incognito.

During these visits, a mortal might catch a genies eye. Friendship forms, romance blooms, and sometimes children result. These children are genasi: individuals with ties to two worlds, yet belonging to neither. Some genasi are born of mortal-genie unions, others have two genasi as parents, and a rare few have a genie further up their family tree, manifesting an elemental heritage that's lain dormant for generations.

Occasionally, genasi result from exposure to a surge of elemental power, through phenomena such as an eruption from the Inner Planes or a planar convergence. Elemental energy saturates any creatures in the area and might alter their nature enough that their offspring with other mortals are born as genasi.

In contrast, water and earth genasi have no common history. Individuals have difficulty tracing their own lineage, and bloodlines occasionally skip a generation or two. The distant land of Zakhara is known only in legends to most inhabitants of Faerun. There, genies and spellcasters enter into bargains, and genasi can result from such pacts. Those genasi have been sources of great weal and woe in the history of that land.

entries.name: Genasi Names
entries: Genasi use the naming conventions of the people among whom they were raised. They might later assume distinctive names to capture their heritage, such as Flame, Ember, Wave, or Onyx.

entries.name: Frozen Form
entries: You have resistance to cold damage, and cannot be frozen, however you have weakness to fire damage. You're also naturally adapted to cold climates, as described in chapter 5 of the Dungeon Master's Guide.

entries.name: Command the Blizzard
entries: You know the {@spell Frostbite} cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell Armor of Agathys} spell once with this trait as a 1st-level spell, and you regain the ability to cast it this way when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

With ancestors hailing from the frozen boundary between the Planes of Water and Air, Ice Genasi are a hearty people, hardened against the cold and no stranger to cruel environments, finding ways to prosper in even the most unforgiving landscapes.

While some take more after their mortal parents, those with stronger ties to their elemental genealogy often have pallid skin that is cold to the touch, and glimmers under the light. Their hair can often be translucent, sometimes even frozen solid atop their heads, needing to thaw before styling.

Ice Genasi are often uncomfortable in the heat, but can assimilate in average climates, although their own towns in the colder regions of the world are home to beautiful architecture built from the ice itself.

Those who think of other planes at all consider them remote, distant realms, but planar influence can be felt throughout the world. It sometimes manifests in beings who, through an accident of birth, carry the power of the planes in their blood. The genasi are one such people, the offspring of genies and mortals.

The distant land of Zakhara is known only in legends to most inhabitants of Faerun. There, genies and spellcasters enter into bargains, and genasi can result from such pacts. Those genasi have been sources of great weal and woe in the history of that land.

entries.name: Genasi Names
entries: Genasi use the naming conventions of the people among whom they were raised. They might later assume distinctive names to capture their heritage, such as Flame, Ember, Wave, or Onyx.

entries.name: Burnt for Eons
entries: Your elemental ancestors had already burnt brightly and been extinguished for eons before the birth of your people, a timeless existence that you have inherited. The first time you would be required to make a saving throw against {@condition exhaustion} in a day, you can call upon the nature of your people, automatically succeeding on the saving throw. Once you use this trait, you must complete a long rest before you can do so again.

entries.name: Stir The Embers
entries: You know the {@spell Poison Spray} cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell Hellish Rebuke} spell once with this trait as a 1st-level spell, and you regain the ability to cast it this way when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for these spells.
With ancestry originating from the long since burned out reaches of the plane of fire, Ash Genasi have inherited the calm and patient nature of their extinguished ancestors.

Most Ash Genasi have grayed skin and subdued features, their faces sometimes being nearly featureless, as if pieces of them had simply crumbled away. In many cases their skin can even flake away and float in the wind like the cinders from a fire, though traces of the fire that once blazed within their ancestors can be found in the hair and eyes of some.
They often find their homes in caves and mountains, some even gravitating towards volcanoes, seeking some reminder of the fire which their ancestors were born from.

Those who think of other planes at all consider them remote, distant realms, but planar influence can be felt throughout the world. It sometimes manifests in beings who, through an accident of birth, carry the power of the planes in their blood. The genasi are one such people, the offspring of genies and mortals.

The Elemental Planes are often inhospitable to natives of the Material Plane: crushing earth, searing flames, boundless skies, and endless seas make visiting these places dangerous for even a short time. The distant land of Zakhara is known only in legends to most inhabitants of Faerun. There, genies and spellcasters enter into bargains, and genasi can result from such pacts. Those genasi have been sources of great weal and woe in the history of that land.

entries.name: Genasi Names
entries: Genasi use the naming conventions of the people among whom they were raised. They might later assume distinctive names to capture their heritage, such as Flame, Ember, Wave, or Onyx.

entries.name: Dust in the Wind
entries: You can allow your form to fall apart like your ancestors, carried by the breeze along the path of least resistance. As a reaction to taking damage, you can teleport up to 30 feet, releasing enough of yourself to {@condition blinded|phb|blind} your opponents. Every creature within 5 feet of the point you teleport from must succeed on a constitution saving throw or else be blinded until the end of your next turn. The DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier. Once you use this ability you cannot do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Eons of Erosion
entries: You can cast the {@spell Dust Devil} spell once with this trait, requiring no material components, and you regain the ability to cast it this way when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

The elemental plane of earth is considered to be the most resilient of all. But at the edge of the plane, where the earth faces elemental chaos, even the hardiest of stones are ground to dust. The elementals of this region have given birth to a race who can weather all storms, as their ancestors have been weathered by far worse.

Their features are smooth, usually considered quite beautiful by those who observe them, though it hides a fierce strength of both body and will underneath. Although many have coloration resembling the more common stones of the world, their skin is incredibly fair, and it is not entirely uncommon to see the odd gem tone in one of their kind, akin to a diamond in the rough.

Those who think of other planes at all consider them remote, distant realms, but planar influence can be felt throughout the world. It sometimes manifests in beings who, through an accident of birth, carry the power of the planes in their blood. The genasi are one such people, the offspring of genies and mortals.

The Elemental Planes are often inhospitable to natives of the Material Plane: crushing earth, searing flames, boundless skies, and endless seas make visiting these places dangerous for even a short time. During these visits, a mortal might catch a genies eye. Friendship forms, romance blooms, and sometimes children result. entries: Genasi use the naming conventions of the people among whom they were raised. They might later assume distinctive names to capture their heritage, such as Flame, Ember, Wave, or Onyx.

entries.name: Unchoked Existence
entries: Adapted to a life surrounded by less than ideal air conditions, you are able to hold your breath for up to 1 hour.

entries.name: Darkvision.
entries: Due to years of seeing through a smoky haze, you can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Breathe the Obscurity
entries: You know the {@spell Minor Illusion} cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell Fog Cloud} spell once with this trait as a 1st-level spell, and you regain the ability to cast it this way when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

Those who think of other planes at all consider them remote, distant realms, but planar influence can be felt throughout the world. It sometimes manifests in beings who, through an accident of birth, carry the power of the planes in their blood. The genasi are one such people, the offspring of genies and mortals.

The Elemental Planes are often inhospitable to natives of the Material Plane: crushing earth, searing flames, boundless skies, and endless seas make visiting these places dangerous for even a short time. The powerful genies, however, do not face such troubles when venturing into the mortal world. They adapt well to the mingled elements of the Material Plane, and they sometimes visit whether of their own volition or compelled by magic. Some genies can adopt mortal guise and travel incognito.

During these visits, a mortal might catch a genies eye. Friendship forms, romance blooms, and sometimes children result. These children are genasi: individuals with ties to two worlds, yet belonging to neither. Some genasi are born of mortal-genie unions, others have two genasi as parents, and a rare few have a genie further up their family tree, manifesting an elemental heritage that's lain dormant for generations.

Occasionally, genasi result from exposure to a surge of elemental power, through phenomena such as an eruption from the Inner Planes or a planar convergence. Elemental energy saturates any creatures in the area and might alter their nature enough that their offspring with other mortals are born as genasi.

entries.name: Heirs to Elemental Power
entries: Genasi inherit something from both sides of their dual nature. They resemble humans but have unusual skin color (red, green, blue, or gray), and there is something odd about them. The elemental blood flowing through their veins manifests differently in each genasi, often as magical power.

Seen in silhouette, a genasi can usually pass for human. Those of earth or water descent tend to be heavier, while those of air or fire tend to be lighter. A given genasi might have some features reminiscent of the mortal parent (pointed ears from an elf, a stockier frame and thick hair from a dwarf, small hands and feet from a halfling, exceedingly large eyes from a gnome, and so on).
Genasi almost never have contact with their elemental parents. Genies seldom have interest in their mortal offspring, seeing them as accidents. Many feel nothing for their genasi children at all.

Some genasi live as outcasts, driven into exile for their unsettling appearance and strange magic, or assuming leadership of savage humanoids and weird cults in untamed lands. Others gain positions of great influence, especially where elemental beings are revered. A few genasi leave the Material Plane to find refuge in the households of their genie parents.

entries.name: Wild and Confident
entries: Genasi rarely lack confidence, seeing themselves as equal to almost any challenge in their path. This certainty might manifest as graceful self-assurance in one genasi and as arrogance in another. Such self-confidence can sometimes blind genasi to risk, and their great plans often get them and others into trouble.
Too much failure can chip away at even a genasis sense of self, so they constantly push themselves to improve, honing their talents and perfecting their craft.

entries.name: Genasi Lands
entries: As rare beings, genasi might go their entire lives without encountering another one of their kind. There are no great genasi cities or empires. Genasi seldom have communities of their own and typically adopt the cultures and societies into which they are born. The more strange their appearance, the harder time they have. Many genasi lose themselves in teeming cities, where their distinctiveness hardly raises an eyebrow in places accustomed to a variety of different people.

Those living on the frontier, though, have a much harder time. People there tend to be less accepting of differences. Sometimes a cold shoulder and a suspicious glare are the best genasi can hope for; in more backward places, they face ostracism and even violence from people who mistake them for fiends. Facing a hard life, these genasi seek isolation in the wilds, making their homes in mountains or forests, near lakes, or underground.

Most air and fire genasi in the Realms are descendants of the djinn and efreet who once ruled Calimshan. When those rulers were overthrown, their planetouched children were scattered. Over thousands of years, the bloodlines of those genasi have spread into other lands. Though far from common, air and fire genasi are more likely to be found in the western regions of Faerun, along the coast from Calimshan north up to the Sword Coast, and into the Western Heartlands to the east. Some remain in their ancient homeland.

In contrast, water and earth genasi have no common history. Individuals have difficulty tracing their own lineage, and bloodlines occasionally skip a generation or two. Many earth genasi originated in the North and spread out from there. Water genasi come from coastal areas, the largest concentration of them hailing from the regions surrounding the Sea of Fallen Stars.

The distant land of Zakhara is known only in legends to most inhabitants of Faerun. There, genies and spellcasters enter into bargains, and genasi can result from such pacts. Those genasi have been sources of great weal and woe in the history of that land.

entries.name: Genasi Names
entries: Genasi use the naming conventions of the people among whom they were raised. They might later assume distinctive names to capture their heritage, such as Flame, Ember, Wave, or Onyx.

entries.name: Inconsistent Form
entries: Your body is solid, but only barely so. As a reaction to an attack being made against you, you can relax your body into a more fluid form, gaining a bonus to your AC equal to half your proficiency bonus rounded down (minimum of one). You may use this feature a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier and regain all expended uses at the end of a long rest.

entries.name: Journey the Mire
entries: You know the {@spell Thorn Whip} cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell Entangle} spell once with this trait as a 1st-level spell, and you regain the ability to cast it this way when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for these spells.
Between the Planes of Earth and Water lies a Plane of Ooze, a vast swamp inhabited by primordial beings and overgrown plants.

The elementals of this plane lack  a rigid physical form, and their Genasi descendants often inherit this trait in... less than attractive ways. Their features are often shades of green or brown, their eyes murky and their skin slick and oily.

Ooze Genasi are typically avoided in most civilized areas, assumed to be sick or at the very least unhygenic. Due to this fact, they are especially reclusive, often living either alone or in small tribes within the swamps of the material plane which remind them of their ancestral home.

Those who think of other planes at all consider them remote, distant realms, but planar influence can be felt throughout the world. It sometimes manifests in beings who, through an accident of birth, carry the power of the planes in their blood. The genasi are one such people, the offspring of genies and mortals.

The Elemental Planes are often inhospitable to natives of the Material Plane: crushing earth, searing flames, boundless skies, and endless seas make visiting these places dangerous for even a short time. The powerful genies, however, do not face such troubles when venturing into the mortal world. They adapt well to the mingled elements of the Material Plane, and they sometimes visit whether of their own volition or compelled by magic. Some genies can adopt mortal guise and travel incognito.

During these visits, a mortal might catch a genies eye. Friendship forms, romance blooms, and sometimes children result. These children are genasi: individuals with ties to two worlds, yet belonging to neither. Some genasi are born of mortal-genie unions, others have two genasi as parents, and a rare few have a genie further up their family tree, manifesting an elemental heritage that's lain dormant for generations.

Occasionally, genasi result from exposure to a surge of elemental power, through phenomena such as an eruption from the Inner Planes or a planar convergence. Elemental energy saturates any creatures in the area and might alter their nature enough that their offspring with other mortals are born as genasi.

entries.name: Genasi Names
entries: Genasi use the naming conventions of the people among whom they were raised. They might later assume distinctive names to capture their heritage, such as Flame, Ember, Wave, or Onyx.

entries.name: Salt the Wound
entries: Immediately after making a melee weapon attack, you can make an unarmed strike as a bonus action, dealing poison damage equal to your level. You may use this feature a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier and regain all expended uses at the end of a long rest.

entries.name: Preserve the Material
entries: You know the {@spell Sapping Sting} cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell Purify Food and Drink} spell once with this trait as a 1st-level spell, and you regain the ability to cast it this way when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

Those who think of other planes at all consider them remote, distant realms, but planar influence can be felt throughout the world. entries.name: Genasi Names
entries: Genasi use the naming conventions of the people among whom they were raised. They might later assume distinctive names to capture their heritage, such as Flame, Ember, Wave, or Onyx.

entries.name: Brilliance in their Blood
entries: Your body is acclimated to the raw radiance that flows within it, you gain resistance to radiant damage and cannot be blinded by magical means.

entries.name: Herald the Light
entries: You can cast the {@spell Moonbeam} spell once with this trait, requiring no material components, and you regain the ability to cast it this way when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

While Aasimars are born from a celestial parent or ancestor, Radiance Genasi are descended from elementals of pure radiant energy, originating from the brink of the plane of fire on the border of elemental chaos.
Their eyes glow intensely, and their hair is translucent, with a light visible within. Light courses through their veins, begging to be let out, constrained only by the mortal form.
Radiance Genasi are often drawn towards a life of religion or service, though some reject celestial beings and gods, believing them to be impure compared to their own ancestors.

Those who think of other planes at all consider them remote, distant realms, but planar influence can be felt throughout the world. It sometimes manifests in beings who, through an accident of birth, carry the power of the planes in their blood. The genasi are one such people, the offspring of genies and mortals.
